45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.
YVONNE ABRAHAMOur poor, persecuted presidentHas any president, living or dead, suffered as much as President Trump?

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

‘Never seen anything like this:’ State lawmakers face multiple crises and a time crunchThe budget. Police reform. COVID legislation. So many bills, so little time.

Ghislaine Maxwell tried ‘to flee’ when FBI showed up to arrest her in N.H., prosecutors say  The dramatic recounting of the arrest came in a legal filing prosecutors submitted Monday in US District Court for the Southern District in Manhattan, where Maxwell, 58, is slated for arraignment Tuesday on six felony counts including conspiracy to entice minors to travel to engage in illegal sex acts and perjury.

Lori Loughlin wants the lien on her $18-million Los Angeles house removedFormer “Full House” star Lori Loughlin and her husband, both slated for sentencing Aug. 21 for paying bribes to get their daughters into USC as phony crew recruits, want the government to remove a lien placed on the real-life house they put up as collateral in March 2019 so they could be freed on bond.

Actress Naya Rivera, who rose to fame as Santana on ‘Glee,’ dies at 33Naya Rivera, a singer and actress who played a gay cheerleader on the hit TV musical comedy “Glee,” was found dead Monday in a Southern California lake. She was 33.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

20 years ago, R.I. lawmakers ignored calls for change after a Black Providence police officer was killed by his own colleagues. Will this time be different?Those who recall the aftermath of Cornel Young Jr.'s death are skeptical that the Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights will be reformed.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.
